title: What are some characteristics of secular and sacred music? - Quora

response.answer_text: Strange question. All music not connected with god could be said to be secular. If you’re including songs with music then there are too many “secular” pieces covering too wide a number of styles and subjects to generalise about characteristics. The only meaningful characteristic for secular music is that it is not about god or religion. Discussing the characteristics of sacred music makes sense on its own, but that isn’t what the question asks. Asking about the characteristics of secular music is like, for example, asking about the characteristics of music not-concerned with love. All you can really say to that would be that the characteristic is that it doesn’t concern itself with love.

Since Bach’s secular cantatas sound like his sacred cantatas and Mozart’s requiem sounds like his other compositions, it would seem that key, tempo, time signatures, etc. are the same. Other examples; ‘What Child Is This’ is the same song as ‘Greensleeves’ and ‘People Get Ready’ sounds like other Curtis Mayfield compositions except for the lyrics. Even lyrics can be virtually the same, i.e. they can praise England or a King or America or a person (Fat Boy Slim’s ‘Praise You’.
